content.description: Good climbing with tricky pro to a cruxy bulge shortly before the anchors.
content.protection: Pro to 2.5". Some offset cams would be nice. Bolted anchors.
content.location: To the right of "Black and Tan" about 30'.

content.description: Great holds lead up to a few bulges that are protected by bolts with great clipping holds.  Look for some great side pulls and have fun. Little run out up to the chains for some spice.
content.protection: Standard rack with quick draws for bolts.  Great chain anchors to rap down.
content.location: Leftmost route.  Belay by the bush. Rap off from chains.

climbs.name: Take the Plunge
climbs.fa: Jay Foley, Donna Longo and friends?

content.description:
Take the Plunge is a nice direct way up to the next anchor left of Comales Tamale.  Jay's book shows 4 different routes reaching this anchor, this is the leftmost of these options.  It's presumably named for the springtime starting conditions... in the creek. 

  Start just left of the black streak, boulder through a steep bulge off the ground (crux).  Enter a shallow right-facing corner with two cracks.  These cracks turn into seams as the difficulty eases.
content.protection: Nuts and cams to 2".   2-bolt anchor with chains at the top.
content.location: Take the Plunge is the leftmost line leading to the 2-bolt anchor left of Comales Tamale on the Water Wall; it goes up just left of the Black Streak.

content.description:
This bolted line right of Black & Tan isn't in the book. 

  Climb a committing lieback start to reach the first bolt.  This first hard part can be protected with a small cam.  Move right under a small overhang, then head up to reach the second bolt.  Pass another roof and climb thin face to the top.
content.protection: A #1 TCU or #0.2 x4 camalot or medium nut or big stick clip to 5 bolts, to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.location: The bolted line right of Black & Tan ; it is the 4th line with bolts from the left end of Leaning Boulder Wall.

content.description: A fun route on good stone with a sustained section of climbing through the middle.
content.protection: Bolts and gear to 1.5". Bolted anchors.

content.description:
Another quality line on Water Wall, Open Books starts up 3 open book features, then turns a roof at the top. 

  Start in the first open book, step right on a ledge, head up the 2nd open book (still easy), step right and enter the 3rd open book.  A technical crux guards the exit stepping left out of this last corner, which is followed by easy climbing to the headwall.  Clip a piton with a big reach (can be backed up with gear), and turn the tricky steep section- the 2nd crux of the route- to the big ledge and the anchor.
content.protection: Cams and nuts to 2".  A fixed piton protects the upper crux.   3-bolt anchor, with quicklinks equipped for rappelling, is found on the ledge at the top (and is likely new since it isn't mentioned in the books).
content.location: Middle to right side of Water Wall. Just left of Gothic Pillar, look for 3 open book/wide groove features, each one to the right of the one below it.

content.description: Follow discontinuous crack system between Open Books and Gothic Pillar.  Likely crux low on the route, with another passing the bulge at the top.
content.protection: Small wires through #2 Camelot.  Belay off tree at the top (original belay for Open Books), walk off.  No fixed gear. Horizontal placements are important on this route.
content.location: Start right of Open Books, look for discontinuous finger crack above.

climbs.name: Gothic Pillar
climbs.fa: Jay Foley, Donna Longo, and friends?

content.description: Gothic Pillar is a nice 5.6 climb at Comales, with enough features to make it beginner- and kid-friendly.Start right of an alcove/indentation in the rock. Gear is kind of tricky or hard to find for the first 20', which may worry some 5.6 leaders. But soon enough you reach a crack in a left-facing corner. Follow it, and the pillar it forms, upÂ to a low-angled, featured face.
content.protection: Nuts and cams to 2"; 2-bolt anchor with chains at the top.
content.location: The second route with an anchor from the right end of Water Wall.

content.description: A vegetated alternative that shares anchors with "Aussie Avalanche" and "Take the Plunge".
content.location: To the right of "Aussie Avalanche". Shares anchors with "Aussie Avalanche" and "Take the Plunge".

content.description: I did not find this to be particularly dirty, but I can see how it got the name.  Fun climb and more worth doing than the name suggests.  I have found all routes on this crag to have solid rock for placing protection.
content.protection: Standard rack.  I did place a few small cams and medium nuts...
content.location: Just to the right of Gothic Pillar, up the hil about 10 feet in the obvious corner.

climbs.name: Comales Tamale
climbs.fa: Sean Wood, Patrick Larkin, Jay Foley

content.description:
Comales Tamale is the tallest and probably the most aesthetic line on the Water Wall. 

  Fun moves in a shallow right facing corner as you step right past one roof, then turn a second roof on good hand jams with many features.  The steepness eases for a short section before a steep final headwall with 2 bolts, which can be avoided to the left, keeping the route at 5.8. "5.8-climbing topropers" will be happier with a directional piece protecting this variation.
content.protection: Nuts and cams to 2" to supplement the 2 bolts.   2-bolt anchor with chains at the top.   Use a 60m rope to toprope.
content.location: Middle of the Water Wall, pick out the highest anchor visible, with 2 bolts below it leading through the headwall.

content.description: This is a toprope problem between "Take the Plunge" and Aussie Avalanche". The crux is about 1/3 of the way up. It involve dicing your way a blank-looking bulge in a black water streak.
content.location: Between "Take the Plunge" and Aussie Avalanche".

climbs.name: Black and Tan
climbs.fa: Jay Foley, Donna Longo and friends?

content.description:
Black & Tan is a fun 5.10 climb on the Leaning Boulder/Water Wall.   Climb an easy start to a single hard move before clipping the first bolt (can place a cam first).  Step right and pull on positive holds on a bulge/prow. Above, you'll turn a small roof and reach a technical face to one last bulge [had a fixed pin, now missing] before the chains. 

  The clean tan face to the left can be toproped at a slightly harder grade.
content.protection: 2 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.   Bring a light rack of nuts and cams.
content.location: Black & Tan is the 3rd bolted line from the left end of Leaning Boulder Wall.

content.description: Crux at the start. Then pretty much cruiser to the top with fun climbing.
content.protection: Gear to 2". Wireds and tri-cams are useful.
content.location: To the right of "Take the Plunge" of which it shares anchors.

content.description:
The lower wall in Comales Canyon. The stream/river runs right by the base of the wall in places. West facing so a bit of afternoon sun, though the hang at the base stays shaded and some routes are shaded by trees. The wall is up to 100' tall and mostly lower angle with many easy to moderate mixed routes. 

  The first wall the the stream runs along also has a handful of routes on it as well as another wall further up stream from Water Wall.
